clusters.title: Poland says it downed drones in its airspace during Russian attacks on Ukraine
clusters.neutral_headline: Poland Downs Drones in Airspace During Russian Attacks
bullet_summary: Prime minister Donald Tusk meanwhile said in his latest update that he is in “constant contact” with Nato secretary general Mark Rutte
The Polish military said early Wednesday that it had downed drones that violated its airspace as Russia launched aerial attacks on Ukraine
The Polish prime minister, Donald Tusk, said early on Thursday that operations were continuing and that he was in “constant contact” with the Nato secretary general, Mark Rutte
Tusk called for an emergency meeting of the council of ministers at 8am local time, a government spokesman said

items.title: Poland says it downed drones in its airspace during Russian attacks on Ukraine
items.standfirst: Apparent Russian drones and missiles have entered NATO members' airspace several times during Russia's war​ in Ukraine but no NATO country has ever tried to shoot them down.
items.content: Apparent Russian drones and missiles have entered NATO members' airspace several times during Russia's war​ in Ukraine but no NATO country has ever tried to shoot them down.

items.content: The Polish military said early Wednesday that it had downed drones that violated its airspace as Russia launched aerial attacks on Ukraine. France 24's Gulliver Cragg reports from Kyiv.

items.title: Sybiha: Drones in Poland proof of Putin's escalation

items.title: Poland shoots down drones over its territory amid Russian attack on Ukraine
items.standfirst: Donald Tusk says operation was launched after ‘repeated violations of Polish airspace’Follow the latest updates livePoland scrambled its own and Nato air defences to shoot down drones that entered its airspace on Wednesday during a Russian attack on Ukraine in what the Polish army called an “act of aggression” as Warsaw got involved in the war in its neighbouring country for the first time.The Polish prime minister, Donald Tusk, said early on Thursday that operations were continuing and that he was in “constant contact” with the Nato secretary general, Mark Rutte. Tusk called for an emergency meeting of the council of ministers at 8am local time, a government spokesman said. Continue reading...
items.content: Donald Tusk says operation was launched after ‘repeated violations of Polish airspace’Follow the latest updates livePoland scrambled its own and Nato air defences to shoot down drones that entered its airspace on Wednesday during a Russian attack on Ukraine in what the Polish army called an “act of aggression” as Warsaw got involved in the war in its neighbouring country for the first time.The Polish prime minister, Donald Tusk, said early on Thursday that operations were continuing and that he was in “constant contact” with the Nato secretary general, Mark Rutte. Tusk called for an emergency meeting of the council of ministers at 8am local time, a government spokesman said. Continue reading...

items.title: Poland says it shot down Russian drones in its airspace for the first time in Ukraine war
items.standfirst: Poland’s military said it scrambled its own and NATO allied air defenses to shoot down Russian drones on Wednesday after they crossed from neighboring Ukraine, the first time in the Ukraine war that Warsaw has engaged Russian assets in its airspace.
items.content: Poland’s military said it scrambled its own and NATO allied air defenses to shoot down Russian drones on Wednesday after they crossed from neighboring Ukraine, the first time in the Ukraine war that Warsaw has engaged Russian assets in its airspace.

items.content: In an unprecedented escalation, Polish and allied jets fired on “hostile objects” violating Polish airspace during a Russian assault on Ukraine—marking the first such use of force by a NATO country

items.title: Poland downs drones that violated its airspace during Russian attack on Ukraine
items.standfirst: The Polish military early Wednesday said it downed drones that violated its airspace as Russia launched a wave of aerial attacks on neighbouring Ukraine. The downing marks the first time that a NATO country has shot down missiles and drones during Russia's three-and-a-half year war.
items.content: The Polish military early Wednesday said it downed drones that violated its airspace as Russia launched a wave of aerial attacks on neighbouring Ukraine. The downing marks the first time that a NATO country has shot down missiles and drones during Russia's three-and-a-half year war.

clusters.title: Trump ‘not thrilled’ over Israeli attack in Qatar
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Strikes Qatar, Targeting Hamas Officials
bullet_summary: US President Donald Trump said he’s “not thrilled” about Israel’s deadly attack on Hamas in Qatar that targeted a reside
President Trump said Tuesday he's "very unhappy" after Israel's military targeted members of Hamas in Qatar's capital of Doha
Six people were killed in Israeli attack on Doha, but Hamas senior leaders are reported to have survived
US President Donald Trump did not agree with Israel's choice to conduct strikes against Hamas inside US ally Qatar, the White House said Tuesday

items.title: Trump appears sidelined as the US caught unawares by Israel’s unprecedented strikes on Qatar
items.standfirst: The White House is caught between supporting Israel’s war against Hamas and patching up relations with a key US ally in the regionFull report: Israel launches airstrikes against top Hamas members in Qatar for Gaza ceasefire talksIn the aftermath of Israeli airstrikes targeting Hamas negotiators in the heart of Qatar’s capital Doha, the White House appeared sidelined from halting a conflict that Donald Trump has claimed only he could mediate.As details of the diplomatic flurry before Tuesday’s extraordinary strike were revealed, it was claimed that the White House had little say in how Israel opened its latest front in its war against Hamas – this one on a US ally hosting negotiations days after Trump had claimed he was close to reaching a deal. Continue reading...
items.content: The White House is caught between supporting Israel’s war against Hamas and patching up relations with a key US ally in the regionFull report: Israel launches airstrikes against top Hamas members in Qatar for Gaza ceasefire talksIn the aftermath of Israeli airstrikes targeting Hamas negotiators in the heart of Qatar’s capital Doha, the White House appeared sidelined from halting a conflict that Donald Trump has claimed only he could mediate.As details of the diplomatic flurry before Tuesday’s extraordinary strike were revealed, it was claimed that the White House had little say in how Israel opened its latest front in its war against Hamas – this one on a US ally hosting negotiations days after Trump had claimed he was close to reaching a deal. items.title: Israel strikes Doha in attack it says targeted Hamas officials
items.standfirst: Israel on Tuesday launched an airstrike in Qatar that hit a building used for ceasefire negotiations between Hamas and Israel. Although Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the attack targeted senior Hamas officials, the UN and leaders around the world, including the US, condemned the attack as a violation of Qatar's national sovereignty.
items.content: Israel on Tuesday launched an airstrike in Qatar that hit a building used for ceasefire negotiations between Hamas and Israel. Although Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the attack targeted senior Hamas officials, the UN and leaders around the world, including the US, condemned the attack as a violation of Qatar's national sovereignty.

items.title: 'Cracks are showing' in the US-Israel relationship as Israel strikes Doha
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump did not agree with Israel's choice to conduct strikes against Hamas inside US ally Qatar, the White House said Tuesday. While eliminating Hamas was a "worthy goal," a strike in the Qatari capital Doha "does not advance Israel or America's goals," White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters, reading from a statement. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.
items.content: US President Donald Trump did not agree with Israel's choice to conduct strikes against Hamas inside US ally Qatar, the White House said Tuesday. While eliminating Hamas was a "worthy goal," a strike in the Qatari capital Doha "does not advance Israel or America's goals," White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters, reading from a statement. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.

items.title: Netanyahu claims Doha strike can lead to peace in Gaza
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the strike on Hamas offices in Qatar could “open the door to an end of the war” in Gaza. According to Hamas, five of its members were killed in the attack but the leaders targeted by Israel survived.
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the strike on Hamas offices in Qatar could “open the door to an end of the war” in Gaza. According to Hamas, five of its members were killed in the attack but the leaders targeted by Israel survived.

items.title: Lisa Cook to remain at Federal Reserve while fighting Trump’s attempt to fire her, judge rules
items.standfirst: Agency governor is legally challenging Trump after he sought to remove her, citing unconfirmed mortgage fraud allegationsA federal judge has ruled that Federal Reserve board member Lisa Cook can stay in her post while suing Donald Trump over his unprecedented bid to fire her.Cook is legally challenging the US president after he sought to remove her, citing unconfirmed allegations of mortgage fraud, amid an extraordinary campaign by his administration to strengthen its control over the US central bank. Continue reading...
items.content: Agency governor is legally challenging Trump after he sought to remove her, citing unconfirmed mortgage fraud allegationsA federal judge has ruled that Federal Reserve board member Lisa Cook can stay in her post while suing Donald Trump over his unprecedented bid to fire her.Cook is legally challenging the US president after he sought to remove her, citing unconfirmed allegations of mortgage fraud, amid an extraordinary campaign by his administration to strengthen its control over the US central bank. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A judge ruled Lisa Cook can remain at the Federal Reserve for now.
The ruling is a setback to Donald Trump's effort to fire Cook.
Trump is trying to fire Cook as he presses the Fed to lower rates.
The judge's ruling temporarily blocks Trump from firing Cook.
Cook will likely vote at the upcoming rate-setting meeting.

clusters.title: France faces ‘Block Everything’ shutdown as new PM Lecornu takes office
clusters.neutral_headline: Macron Appoints Lecornu as New French Prime Minister
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, Al Jazeera, BBC World and others

items.title: France faces ‘Block Everything’ shutdown as new PM Lecornu takes office
items.standfirst: France faces a day of disruption Wednesday as the "Block Everything" protests, called by a loose left-wing coalition, threaten to obstruct transport and other services. The protests come as Sébastien Lecornu is set to take the reins as France’s new prime minister amid a gridlocked National Assembly. Follow our live coverage of the day's events as they unfold.
items.content: France faces a day of disruption Wednesday as the "Block Everything" protests, called by a loose left-wing coalition, threaten to obstruct transport and other services. The protests come as Sébastien Lecornu is set to take the reins as France’s new prime minister amid a gridlocked National Assembly. Follow our live coverage of the day's events as they unfold.

items.title: Macron appoints Defense Minister Sebastien Lecornu as new Prime Minister
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday appointed Defense Minister Sebastien Lecornu as his new Prime Minister after François Bayrou tendered his resignation over a vote of no confidence. Lecornu, Macron's third prime minister in the past year, faces the daunting task of passing the national budget through a gridlocked National Assembly.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday appointed Defense Minister Sebastien Lecornu as his new Prime Minister after François Bayrou tendered his resignation over a vote of no confidence. Lecornu, Macron's third prime minister in the past year, faces the daunting task of passing the national budget through a gridlocked National Assembly.

items.title: Macron names close ally Lecornu new PM
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday named armed forces minister and his close ally Sebastien Lecornu as the new prime minister to replace Francois Bayrou as the seventh premier of his mandate. The formal handover of power between Bayrou and Lecornu is due to take place on Wednesday at midday. FRANCE 24's Claire Paccalin reports.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday named armed forces minister and his close ally Sebastien Lecornu as the new prime minister to replace Francois Bayrou as the seventh premier of his mandate. The formal handover of power between Bayrou and Lecornu is due to take place on Wednesday at midday. FRANCE 24's Claire Paccalin reports.

items.title: Macron names close ally Sebastien Lecornu as new French PM
items.standfirst: Sebastien Lecornu, 39, is facing an uphill battle over budget as protests loom in the coming days.
items.content: Sebastien Lecornu, 39, is facing an uphill battle over budget as protests loom in the coming days.

items.title: France's new PM tasked with forging consensus on a 2026 budget
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron has picked defence chief Sébastien Lecornu as his new Prime Minsiter a day after François Bayrou was voted out in parliament. The 39-year-old's immediate priority will be to try and forge consensus on a new budget, before forming a government. If this year's budget were to be carried over into next year, France's fiscal deficit, already the highest in the EU, is predicted to widen further.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron has picked defence chief Sébastien Lecornu as his new Prime Minsiter a day after François Bayrou was voted out in parliament. The 39-year-old's immediate priority will be to try and forge consensus on a new budget, before forming a government. If this year's budget were to be carried over into next year, France's fiscal deficit, already the highest in the EU, is predicted to widen further.

items.title: Macron names ally Sébastien Lecornu as new French PM
items.standfirst: It comes after a vote of confidence ousted François Bayrou after nine months in power.
items.content: It comes after a vote of confidence ousted François Bayrou after nine months in power.

items.title: Emmanuel Macron appoints his third prime minister in a year
items.standfirst: Sébastien Lecornu, a presidential ally, is tasked with bringing France’s divided parties together to pass a budgetSébastien Lecornu, a close ally of Emmanuel Macron, has been appointed prime minister, tasked with consulting France’s divided political parties to try to find a consensus on the budget.The 39-year-old began his political career in the traditional rightwing party of Nicolas Sarkozy before moving to Macron’s centre in 2017 and is seen as fiercely loyal to the president. Continue reading...
items.content: Sébastien Lecornu, a presidential ally, is tasked with bringing France’s divided parties together to pass a budgetSébastien Lecornu, a close ally of Emmanuel Macron, has been appointed prime minister, tasked with consulting France’s divided political parties to try to find a consensus on the budget.The 39-year-old began his political career in the traditional rightwing party of Nicolas Sarkozy before moving to Macron’s centre in 2017 and is seen as fiercely loyal to the president. Continue reading...

items.title: France's ruling government collapses in major blow to President Emmanuel Macron
items.standfirst: France's National Assembly is set to vote for a motion of no confidence in François Bayrou, less than a year after they did the same for Michel Barnier.
items.content: France's National Assembly is set to vote for a motion of no confidence in François Bayrou, less than a year after they did the same for Michel Barnier.

ai_summary: French President Macron appointed Sebastien Lecornu as the new Prime Minister.
Lecornu replaces Francois Bayrou, who was voted out in parliament.
Lecornu faces the task of forging consensus on a new budget.
Protests are expected as Lecornu takes office.
The formal handover of power is scheduled for Wednesday.

items.title: Nepal prime minister quits after deaths at protests sparked by social media ban
items.standfirst: KP Sharma Oli resigns as police meet protests with deadly force, leaving 19 dead, and federal parliament is set alight Nepal’s prime minister has resigned after some of the worst unrest in decades rocked the country this week, set off by a ban on social media and discontent at political corruption and nepotism.KP Sharma Oli’s resignation came a day after widespread protests were met with deadly force by police, leaving 19 dead and hundreds injured. The spark for the protests was a government ban on 26 prominent social media apps, but escalated into a larger mass movement against corruption among political elites. Continue reading...
items.content: KP Sharma Oli resigns as police meet protests with deadly force, leaving 19 dead, and federal parliament is set alight Nepal’s prime minister has resigned after some of the worst unrest in decades rocked the country this week, set off by a ban on social media and discontent at political corruption and nepotism.KP Sharma Oli’s resignation came a day after widespread protests were met with deadly force by police, leaving 19 dead and hundreds injured. The spark for the protests was a government ban on 26 prominent social media apps, but escalated into a larger mass movement against corruption among political elites. Continue reading...

items.content: Nepal's prime minister KP Sharma Oli has resigned after violent anti-corruption protests.

items.title: At least 19 killed in ‘gen Z’ protests against Nepal’s social media ban
items.standfirst: Many demonstrators say they are also on the streets over corruption and nepotism they allege is rampant At least 19 people have been killed during protests in Nepal over a government ban on dozens of online platforms including Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and X.The government has faced mounting criticism after imposing a ban on 26 prominent social media platforms and messaging apps last week because they had missed a deadline to register under new regulations. Continue reading...
items.content: Many demonstrators say they are also on the streets over corruption and nepotism they allege is rampant At least 19 people have been killed during protests in Nepal over a government ban on dozens of online platforms including Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and X.The government has faced mounting criticism after imposing a ban on 26 prominent social media platforms and messaging apps last week because they had missed a deadline to register under new regulations. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Nepal's Prime Minister resigned after deadly anti-corruption protests.
The protests were sparked by a ban on social media apps.
At least 19 people were killed in clashes.
The parliament building was set on fire.
Protesters also demonstrated against corruption and nepotism.

clusters.title: Princeton academic Elizabeth Tsurkov released from militia captivity in Iraq
clusters.neutral_headline: Israeli-Russian Researcher Freed After Captivity in Iraq
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, Al Jazeera, BBC World and others

items.title: Princeton academic Elizabeth Tsurkov released from militia captivity in Iraq
items.standfirst: Israeli-Russian academic Elizabeth Tsurkov was released from captivity in Iraq, Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Suani and US President Donald Trump announced Tuesday, after more than two years of being held hostage by a Shiite militia. Tsurkov was researching pro-Iran factions when she was kidnapped in March 2023.
items.content: Israeli-Russian academic Elizabeth Tsurkov was released from captivity in Iraq, Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Suani and US President Donald Trump announced Tuesday, after more than two years of being held hostage by a Shiite militia. Tsurkov was researching pro-Iran factions when she was kidnapped in March 2023.

items.content: US President Trump confirms Elizabeth Tsurkov freed after being held by Iraqi group amid spy claims.

items.title: Abducted Israeli-Russian researcher Elizabeth Tsurkov freed in Iraq

items.content: A Princeton student "tortured for many months" by Iraqi militia is now in the US embassy, President Trump says.

items.title: Israeli-Russian graduate student freed after 903 days in Hezbollah captivity
items.standfirst: Elizabeth Tsurkov, who entered Iraq to do research for Princeton, had gone missing in Iraq in early 2023Israeli-Russian academic and Princeton student Elizabeth Tsurkov has been released after being kidnapped by Kata’ib Hezbollah and spending more than two years in captivity, Donald Trump said in a post on social media.“I am pleased to report that Elizabeth Tsurkov, a Princeton Student, whose sister is an American Citizen, was just released by Kata’ib Hezbollah (MILITANT Hezbollah), and is now safely in the American Embassy in Iraq after being tortured for many months. I will always fight for JUSTICE, and never give up. HAMAS, RELEASE THE HOSTAGES, NOW!” the US president wrote in a TruthSocial post on Tuesday. Continue reading...
items.content: Elizabeth Tsurkov, who entered Iraq to do research for Princeton, had gone missing in Iraq in early 2023Israeli-Russian academic and Princeton student Elizabeth Tsurkov has been released after being kidnapped by Kata’ib Hezbollah and spending more than two years in captivity, Donald Trump said in a post on social media.“I am pleased to report that Elizabeth Tsurkov, a Princeton Student, whose sister is an American Citizen, was just released by Kata’ib Hezbollah (MILITANT Hezbollah), and is now safely in the American Embassy in Iraq after being tortured for many months. I will always fight for JUSTICE, and never give up. HAMAS, RELEASE THE HOSTAGES, NOW!” the US president wrote in a TruthSocial post on Tuesday. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Israeli-Russian researcher Elizabeth Tsurkov was released from captivity in Iraq.
She was held by a Shiite militia for over two years.
Tsurkov was researching pro-Iran factions when kidnapped.
Donald Trump confirmed her release.
She is now safely in the American Embassy in Iraq.

clusters.title: Ethiopia launches Africa's largest hydroelectric dam, sparking Egyptian protest
clusters.neutral_headline: Ethiopia Inaugurates Africa's Largest Hydroelectric Dam
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, NPR News, Guardian World

items.title: Ethiopia launches Africa's largest hydroelectric dam, sparking Egyptian protest
items.standfirst: Standing 170 metres high and stretching nearly 2 km across the Blue Nile, Ethiopia has officially unveiled the largest hydroelectric dam in Africa. While it is expected to supply electricity to millions of Ethiopians, it also risks exacerbating tensions with neighbouring Egypt and Sudan, who are concerned about their water reserves.
items.content: Standing 170 metres high and stretching nearly 2 km across the Blue Nile, Ethiopia has officially unveiled the largest hydroelectric dam in Africa. While it is expected to supply electricity to millions of Ethiopians, it also risks exacerbating tensions with neighbouring Egypt and Sudan, who are concerned about their water reserves.

items.title: Ethiopia inaugurates Africa's biggest dam amid regional tensions
items.standfirst: Ethiopia opens Africa's largest hydropower project, the Blue Nile's Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam — a milestone that's sparking alarm in neighboring Sudan and Egypt.
items.content: Ethiopia opens Africa's largest hydropower project, the Blue Nile's Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam — a milestone that's sparking alarm in neighboring Sudan and Egypt.(Image credit: Brian Inganga)

items.title: Ethiopia inaugurates Africa’s largest hydroelectric dam as Egypt rift deepens
items.standfirst: Ethiopian PM says dam will electrify entire region but Egypt fears it could restrict water supply during droughtsEthiopia has inaugurated Africa’s largest hydroelectric dam, a project that could transform the country’s energy sector but may also aggravate tensions with neighbouring Egypt.State media showed the Ethiopian prime minister, Abiy Ahmed, touring the site of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) in Guba district with the Kenyan president, William Ruto, the Somali president, Hassan Sheikh Mohamud, and the African Union chairperson, Mahmoud Ali Youssouf. Continue reading...
items.content: Ethiopian PM says dam will electrify entire region but Egypt fears it could restrict water supply during droughtsEthiopia has inaugurated Africa’s largest hydroelectric dam, a project that could transform the country’s energy sector but may also aggravate tensions with neighbouring Egypt.State media showed the Ethiopian prime minister, Abiy Ahmed, touring the site of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) in Guba district with the Kenyan president, William Ruto, the Somali president, Hassan Sheikh Mohamud, and the African Union chairperson, Mahmoud Ali Youssouf. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Ethiopia inaugurated Africa's largest hydroelectric dam.
The dam is on the Blue Nile River.
The project may exacerbate tensions with Egypt and Sudan.
The dam is expected to supply electricity to millions.
The Ethiopian Prime Minister toured the site.

items.title: Trump orders crackdown on some pharma ads, RFK Jr. releases child health report

A report on child health outcomes was also released.

items.title: More children are obese than underweight, says Unicef

items.content: Traditional, healthy diets are being replaced by ultra-processed foods, often high in sugar and additives, the UN agency says.

clusters.title: Iran resumes cooperation with UN nuclear watchdog under new framework
clusters.neutral_headline: Iran and UN Nuclear Agency Agree to Renew Cooperation
bullet_summary: The UN watchdog will resume its monitoring of Iran's nuclear programme, which will be developed with "greater transparency", said host Egypt's foreign minister
Reported by France24, NPR News

items.title: Iran resumes cooperation with UN nuclear watchdog under new framework
items.standfirst: Iran and the International Atomic Energy Agency agreed to a "new form" of cooperation on Tuesday after Tehran paused the partnership in the wake of its war with Israel in June. The UN watchdog will resume its monitoring of Iran's nuclear programme, which will be developed with "greater transparency", said host Egypt's foreign minister.
items.content: Iran and the International Atomic Energy Agency agreed to a "new form" of cooperation on Tuesday after Tehran paused the partnership in the wake of its war with Israel in June. The UN watchdog will resume its monitoring of Iran's nuclear programme, which will be developed with "greater transparency", said host Egypt's foreign minister.

items.title: Iran and nuclear watchdog sign agreement seeking path to restart cooperation
items.standfirst: Iran and the International Atomic Energy Agency signed an agreement in Cairo to pave the way for resuming cooperation, including on ways of relaunching inspections of Iran's nuclear facilities.
items.content: Iran and the International Atomic Energy Agency signed an agreement in Cairo to pave the way for resuming cooperation, including on ways of relaunching inspections of Iran's nuclear facilities.(Image credit: Khaled Elfiqi)

ai_summary: Iran and the IAEA agreed to a new form of cooperation.
This agreement follows a pause in cooperation.
The UN agency will resume monitoring Iran's nuclear program.
The monitoring will be conducted with greater transparency.
The agreement was signed in Cairo, Egypt.

items.title: Former CBO director says Trump's economy is "dead in the water"
items.standfirst: The Bureau of Labor Statistics on Tuesday said the U.S. added 911,000 fewer jobs than previously reported in the 12-month period ending in March 2025. Douglas Holtz-Eakin, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, joins "The Takeout" to discuss the state of the U.S. economy.
items.content: The Bureau of Labor Statistics on Tuesday said the U.S. added 911,000 fewer jobs than previously reported in the 12-month period ending in March 2025. Douglas Holtz-Eakin, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, joins "The Takeout" to discuss the state of the U.S. economy.

items.title: What to know after BLS says U.S. added 911,000 fewer jobs than previously reported
items.standfirst: The U.S. labor market added 911,000 fewer jobs in the past year than earlier reported, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced on Tuesday. CBS News MoneyWatch correspondent Kelly O'Grady has the details. Then, Douglas Holtz-Eakin, former chief economic adviser for the George W. Bush administration and former director of the Congressional Budget Office, joins with analysis.
items.content: The U.S. labor market added 911,000 fewer jobs in the past year than earlier reported, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced on Tuesday. CBS News MoneyWatch correspondent Kelly O'Grady has the details. Then, Douglas Holtz-Eakin, former chief economic adviser for the George W. Bush administration and former director of the Congressional Budget Office, joins with analysis.

items.title: US created 911,000 fewer jobs through March 2025 than initially reported
items.standfirst: Revision highlights recent concerns about the health of the labor market, and follows a lackluster August jobs reportBusiness live – latest updatesThe US added 911,000 fewer jobs than first estimated for the year to March 2025, the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) announced on Tuesday, highlighting recent concerns about the health of the labor market.The revisions are 50% higher than last year’s adjustment and were on the higher end of Wall Street estimates between 600,000 and 1 million. Continue reading...
items.content: Revision highlights recent concerns about the health of the labor market, and follows a lackluster August jobs reportBusiness live – latest updatesThe US added 911,000 fewer jobs than first estimated for the year to March 2025, the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) announced on Tuesday, highlighting recent concerns about the health of the labor market.The revisions are 50% higher than last year’s adjustment and were on the higher end of Wall Street estimates between 600,000 and 1 million. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The US labor market added 911,000 fewer jobs than previously reported.
This revision covers the twelve-month period ending in March 2025.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics announced the downward revision.
The revision is significantly higher than last year's adjustment.
Experts are discussing the implications for the US economy.

clusters.title: Video shows purported drone strike on Gaza aid flotilla vessel

items.title: Video shows purported drone strike on Gaza aid flotilla vessel
items.standfirst: Video captured the purported drone strike on a Gaza aid flotilla in Tunisian waters, according to organizers for the vessel. Tunisian authorities said the explosion came from inside the vessel, rejecting the claim it was hit off the country’s coast.
items.content: Video captured the purported drone strike on a Gaza aid flotilla in Tunisian waters, according to organizers for the vessel. Tunisian authorities said the explosion came from inside the vessel, rejecting the claim it was hit off the country’s coast.

items.content: Global Sumud Flotilla says a fire was started but Tunisian authorities deny that a drone was involved.

items.title: Main Gaza flotilla ship attacked by drone off Tunisia, organizers say

items.content: The organizers of a Gaza aid flotilla say a drone has struck a one of the ships as the convoy passed through Tunisian waters, sparking a fire on the main deck.

ai_summary: Organizers claim a drone strike hit a Gaza aid flotilla vessel.

Tunisian authorities deny a drone was involved.
A fire was reported on the main deck of the ship.
